import OptionsTable from '../../../components/OptionsTable.astro';

The `new ddd` is a specialized command that inherits from the `new` command base class. It creates new projects
following the Domain-Driven Design (DDD) architectural pattern building 4 projects: Presentation, Domain, Application
and Infrastructure.

## Options

<OptionsTable options={[{
    name: '--name',
    alias: '-n',
    description: 'Project name',
    required: true,
    example: '--name MyDddProject'
}, {
    name: '--output',
    alias: '-o',
    description: 'The output directory',
    required: false,
    example: '--output ./projects/ddd'
}, {
    name: '--presentation',
    alias: '-pre',
    description: 'API type (FastEndpoints, GraphQL)',
    required: false,
    example: '--presentation FastEndpoints'
}, {
    name: '--infrastructure',
    alias: '-inf',
    description: 'Persistence layer (MongoDB, EFCore)',
    required: false,
    example: '--db-type EFCore'
}, {
    name: '--application',
    alias: '-app',
    description: 'Application layer type (MediatR)',
    required: false,
    example: '--application MediatR'
}, {
    name: '--domain',
    alias: '-dom',
    description: 'Domain layer type (Default)',
    required: false,
    example: '--domain Default'
}, {
    name: '--db-type',
    alias: '-db',
    description: 'Database type (SQLServer, PostgreSQL), required if EF Core selected',
    required: false,
    example: '--db-type SQLServer'
}, {
    name: '--skip-interactive',
    description: 'Skips the interactive prompt and uses the default values for all options',
    required: false,
    example: '--skip-interactive'
}]}/>

> Omitting the `--output` option will create the project in the current directory.

> Omitting any other non required option will use the default value.

## Usage

```bash
apiand new ddd --name MyProject --api-type FastEndpoints --db-type MongoDB
```

## Features

- **Multi-Layer Architecture**: Organized into distinct layers (Presentation, Domain, Application, Infrastructure)
- **Domain-Driven Design**: Focused on core business logic and domain models
- **Flexible Infrastructure**: Support for multiple database options (MongoDB, EF Core with SQL Server or PostgreSQL)
- **Presentation Options**: Choose between REST or GraphQL APIs
- **CQRS Pattern**: Clean separation of commands and queries with MediatR
- **Dependency Injection**: Well-structured service registration and configuration

## When to Use

The DDD architecture is ideal for:
- Complex business domains with rich logic
- Enterprise-level applications
- Projects requiring clear separation of concerns
- Applications expected to grow and evolve over time
- Systems where business rules change frequently
- Teams with specialized roles (domain experts, UI developers, etc.)
- Projects where maintainability and scalability are top priorities
